heading: Objective
body: Establish a trust-first first impression that lowers customer stress, builds rapport, and sets clear expectations for a one-price, guest-first experience.

heading: Mindset
body: Walk up with the goal of helping—not selling. Your job in the first minute is comfort + clarity + connection.
quote: People don’t care how much you know until they know how much you care.

heading: Definition: Trust-First Presence
body: A calm, confident, professional presence that makes guests feel safe, respected, and guided—without pressure.

heading: Outcome
body: By the end of this module, the team can execute consistent greetings across walk-in, drive-up, and appointment scenarios using approved word tracks.

heading: 1.0 The Science
body: First impressions are fast, emotional, and sticky. A great greeting reduces uncertainty and creates momentum for discovery and solution-building.

heading: Thin-Slicing
body: People form judgments within seconds based on small cues—especially body language, tone, and confidence.

heading: Halo Effect
body: A positive opening changes how guests interpret everything that follows—people give you more benefit of the doubt.

heading: Primacy Effect
body: What happens first becomes the anchor. If the first minute feels chaotic or pushy, the rest of the process must work harder.

heading: Emotional Contagion
body: Your emotional tone transfers. Calm and confidence reduces guest stress and increases openness to conversation.
notes: Add practice note: record voice tone.

heading: Expectation Confirmation
body: Satisfaction increases when reality meets or exceeds the expectations created in the greeting.

heading: Environment & Context
body: Clean, organized surroundings influence trust. Guests notice the details more than we think.

heading: Mirroring & Matching
body: Subtle matching (pace/tone) increases rapport and comfort—without mimicking.

heading: 2.0 Success Standards
body: These standards make greetings consistent across the store and eliminate the ‘random experience’ problem.

heading: 10-Second Rule
body: Acknowledge every guest within 10 seconds—even if you’re busy—then re-engage within 60 seconds.

heading: Open Body Language
body: Stand tall, shoulders open, hands visible, and feet pointed toward the guest (no crossing arms, no leaning back).

heading: Warm Tone, Not Loud
body: Warm and confident wins. Avoid loud, overly hyped energy that feels salesy.

heading: Name Exchange
body: Offer your name early and ask for theirs. Use their name once naturally—not repeatedly.
bullets: Hi, I’m __|What’s your name?|Nice to meet you, __

heading: Respect Space
body: Approach at an angle, keep comfortable distance, and avoid blocking paths/exits.

heading: Permission-Based Questions
body: Ask permission before moving into discovery. It lowers resistance and improves cooperation.
bullets: Is it okay if…|Would you like…|Do you mind if…

heading: Set the Process Early
body: Explain the next step in one sentence. Don’t overwhelm with the whole process.

heading: No Assumptions
body: Don’t assume budget, credit, trade, timeline, or ‘just looking.’ Ask neutral questions.

heading: One-Price Confidence
body: If price comes up early, anchor one-price to clarity and fairness—then transition to needs and fit.

heading: 3.0 Scenarios
body: Use these as repeatable patterns. Same structure, different words.

heading: Walk-In Scenario
body: Walk-in guests may be browsing or purposeful. Greet promptly and invite their purpose without pressure.

heading: Walk-In Script
body: Hi! Welcome in. I’m [NAME]. What brings you in today—are you looking for something specific, or just starting to browse?

heading: Drive-Up Scenario
body: Drive-up guests often have a specific goal. Meet them quickly and guide without overwhelm.
notes: Approach the vehicle only when appropriate.

heading: Drive-Up Script
body: Welcome to {store_name}. I’m [NAME]. Are you here for something specific, or would you like to see a couple of options that fit what you had in mind?

heading: Appointment Arrival
body: Appointments want recognition and respect for their time. Confirm who/what and move forward smoothly.

heading: Appointment Script
body: Hi [NAME], welcome back—glad you made it in. I’ve got us set up. Before we start, did anything change since we last spoke?

heading: Browser Scenario
body: Browsing guests want space. Acknowledge, offer help, then give room while staying available.

heading: Browser Script
body: Welcome in. Feel free to take your time. If you want pricing, availability, or a quick comparison, I’m right here when you’re ready.

heading: Service/Waiting Area
body: Guests in service are often time-sensitive. Lead with service-first respect, then transition gently if appropriate.

heading: Service Script
body: Hi—welcome in. Are you here for service today, or did you want help with something on the sales side as well?

heading: Bad Weather Adaptation
body: In bad weather, comfort comes first. Reduce stress, offer shelter, then continue the conversation.

heading: Weather Script
body: Let’s get you out of this weather—come on in. Can I get you a water or coffee while we figure out what you’re here for today?

heading: Early Price Question
body: If they ask price immediately, validate, provide clarity, then transition to needs so price has context.

heading: Early Price Script
body: Absolutely—pricing matters. We keep it simple with one clear price so there’s no back-and-forth. Before I point you to the best option, what’s most important to you in the vehicle?

heading: 4.0 Role-Play Focus
body: Practice tone, posture, eye contact, name exchange, and permission-based questions until it’s automatic.

heading: Coach’s Scoring Cues
body: Score each rep on: speed of acknowledgement, warmth, body language, name exchange, purpose question, and next-step clarity.
notes: Add 1–5 scoring rubric in your app if desired.

heading: 5.0 Worksheet Purpose
body: Reinforce first impression mastery and the ‘Four Ways of Contact’ (what we do, how we look, what we say, how we say it).
bullets: What we do|How we look|What we say|How we say it

heading: Reflection Prompt
body: What do guests feel in the first 30 seconds when I approach—safe and guided, or pressured and uncertain?

heading: Self-Check
body: List two greeting habits you will stop and two you will strengthen this week.
